Subjective: Spot on neck; 2 weeks; initially thought was wart; scabs fell off; insect bite; swollen and redder; itches; no pain; no fever; no similar spots elsewhere; no lymph node swelling; worried about skin cancer; request: wants diagnosis and treatment; also experiencing knee pain after running; no severe pain; no other symptoms; no smoking/alcohol; impact on daily life: unable to play soccer due to fatigue; wants to get rid of the spot; prefers freezing method; has memories of abscess in ear; no other skin problems; family history of skin problems (actinic keratosis, squamous cell carcinoma, basal cell carcinoma); no melanoma; no other medical conditions.
Objective: Vitals: not recorded; Physical Exam: spot on neck; 0.5 cm; pinkish-red; slightly redder spot in the middle; no scab; no lymph node swelling; no other skin lesions; knee: not examined
Assessment: Dermatological lesion; possible pyogenic granuloma or atypical mole; ruled out: melanoma; further evaluation needed
Plan: 1. Send picture of lesion to dermatologist for evaluation; 2. Discuss treatment options with patient; 3. Possible treatment: freezing with liquid nitrogen; 4. Follow-up on Friday to discuss dermatologist's advice; 5. Consider biopsy or removal of lesion; 6. Address knee pain in separate consultation
